senses.de: To collect things, often while moving around
senses.ex: She gathered the children's toys that were scattered in the room.

Tips.title: Physical Collection
Tips.description: Often implies collecting tangible items by hand or using tools.
Tips.example: We gathered seashells along the beach.

Tips.title: Action Movement
Tips.description: Involves moving from place to place to collect items or information.
Tips.example: Journalists gather news from various sources.

senses.de: To come together in a group, or to make people do this
senses.ex: They gathered around the campfire to sing songs.

Tips.title: Group Dynamics
Tips.description: Used when people come together socially or for a purpose.
Tips.example: The community gathered at the hall for the annual event.

Tips.title: Unity Implication
Tips.description: Can suggest solidarity or support among a group of people.
Tips.example: The workers gathered in protest of the unfair policies.

senses.ex: From what I can gather, he isn't happy with the decision.

Tips.title: Cognitive Processing
Tips.description: Reflects a mental process of piecing together information.
Tips.example: I gather you're not interested, seeing your lack of enthusiasm.

Tips.title: Indirect Understanding
Tips.description: Indicates comprehension from hints or implications, not direct statements.
Tips.example: From your tone, I gather that you disagree with the plan.

senses.de: To increase gradually in amount or intensity
senses.ex: The storm is gathering force, we should seek shelter.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Intensification
Tips.description: Often used metaphorically to describe the build-up of non-physical things.
Tips.example: He paused to gather his thoughts before speaking.

Tips.title: Progressive Aspect
Tips.description: Suggests a gradually increasing process, not an instantaneous change.
Tips.example: As the deadline approaches, we need to gather momentum.

senses.de: To make fabric hang in loose folds
senses.ex: She gathered the excess fabric at the waist of the dress.

Tips.title: Sewing Specific
Tips.description: In sewing, it refers to creating folds or pleats in fabric.
Tips.example: Gather the curtain fabric evenly for a nice drape.

Tips.title: Aesthetic Adjustments
Tips.description: Used to fine-tune the fit or look of a garment.
Tips.example: Gather the back of the dress to make it more fitted.

Accumulate.wordDefinition:
Accumulate means to gradually collect or build up a large amount or quantity of something over time. For example, you might accumulate wealth over the years by saving or investing.

The main difference between the two words is that accumulate implies a gradual and steady increase or growth over time, while gather simply means to bring things or people together in one place.

Amass.wordDefinition:
The words amass and gather both mean to collect or bring together, but amass usually implies a larger quantity, while gather is more general and can refer to any amount.

For example, you might say that someone 'amassed' a fortune, which suggests a large amount of money, whereas you might say that you 'gathered' some flowers from your garden, which doesn't suggest any particular quantity.

Amass is generally used to describe a larger quantity or accumulation of something, while gather is a more general term for collecting or assembling any amount.

Assemble.wordDefinition: Assemble means to bring different parts or components together to form a larger whole, like assembling a puzzle or assembling furniture.

Cluster.wordDefinition:
Cluster means to group or organize things or people closely together. For example, grapes grow in a cluster on a vine.

Cluster is used when things or people are already close together, while gather is used when things or people need to be brought together from different places.

Collect.wordDefinition:
Both collect and gather are verbs that mean to bring things together, but there is a subtle difference between the two.

Collect usually implies a deliberate effort to accumulate or acquire items of a particular kind or for a specific purpose.

For example, you might collect stamps, coins, or sports memorabilia.

Collect is usually used when talking about building a specific collection while gather has a more general meaning of bringing things together.

Compile.wordDefinition:
Compile means to gather information, data, or materials from different sources and put them together in an organized way.

It is usually used when creating a document, report or book. For example, a writer may compile information from different sources like books, websites, and interviews to write an article.

Compile is used to express the organization of information while gather is for the collection of elements from different places into a unified location.

Garner.wordDefinition:
Both words garner and gather are verbs that refer to the act of collecting or bringing together things.

Garner typically implies that you are collecting something with a specific purpose or goal in mind. For example, you might garner support for a political campaign, or garner evidence to support a legal case.

So, while gather is a more general word that can be used in a variety of contexts, garner tends to be used more specifically when collecting something for a particular reason or outcome.

Harvest.wordDefinition:
Gather means to collect things together, while harvest refers to the process of collecting ripe crops or produce.

For example, one might gather flowers from a garden, but harvest apples from an orchard. Gathering might involve picking up scattered objects or bringing together a group of people.

Harvesting involves collecting crops at the end of a growing season.

Gather is a more general term that can apply to anything from collecting data to picking up toys. Harvest, on the other hand, is mostly reserved for agricultural or food-related contexts.

Round up.wordDefinition:
Round up means to gather things or people that are scattered or difficult to find. For example, cowboys may round up cattle that have strayed from the herd, or police may round up suspects in a crime.

So, in simple terms, gather is used when things or people are already in one place or are easy to find, while round up is used when things or people are scattered or difficult to find.

quotes.Text: I think that theater is a unique way to communicate with people as they gather together with other people they may not even know. It creates a sense of shared community for the time of the performance that hopefully carries over into other aspects of the audience's life because they have shared this experience together.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Pearl Cleage

quotes.Text: There's a sense of aliveness that comes from connection, shared experience. And you see it in every place. You see it when ball players jump up and down, gather at home plate, hugging, and it's not just because they're winning, it's that shared moment, that feeling of - we enter the world alone, we leave alone.
quotes.Title: American Producer
quotes.Name: Peter Guber

quotes.Text: I think that a lot of people, especially as technology began to speed up and we became more distant, we kind of started to lose our appreciation for human contact and gathering and friendships and a lot of the things that we really took for granted.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Jemele Hill

quotes.Text: I feel like I've grown up a bit. I'm a bit more confident, and I've been reading more, and I've had a little more time to myself. I went on this writing trip to gather my thoughts about where and who I am in this world, and why we're all here.
quotes.Title: English Musician
quotes.Name: Imogen Heap

quotes.Text: As an actress, I'm constantly watching different shows and films and am always gathering information and inspiration for characters and techniques to make my performances the best they can be.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Rachel G. Fox

quotes.Text: I show the people I love that I love them by gathering them in my kitchen and feeding them, so no surprise that most of my characters do the same thing.
quotes.Title: English Author
quotes.Name: Jane Green

quotes.Text: The work gets more difficult as you get older. You learn more and you gather more experiences, there is deeper pain and higher highs.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Gwyneth Paltrow

quotes.Text: We must gather our courage. Hold hands and cast aside our divisions. We must embrace what unites us, together we can.
quotes.Title: Haitian Politician
quotes.Name: Jovenel Moise

quotes.Text: The saddest aspect of life right now is that science gathers knowledge faster than society gathers wisdom.
quotes.Title: American Scientist
quotes.Name: Isaac Asimov

quotes.Text: Family gatherings were very important to me growing up.
quotes.Title: Colombian Musician
quotes.Name: Karol G
